entries.content: Ask questions that lead prospects to understanding what they want.
Your role is to help prospects buy, not just sell them.
Understand that people buy based on emotion and justify with logic.
Focus questioning on discovering what the prospect truly wants.
"What would you like to see happen with X by Y time?"
entries.notes: Use X for the area of focus, Y for the timeframe.

entries.content: Identify the prospect's main problem or desired outcome.
Align everything you say after identifying the core problem to solving that specific problem.
Don't just sell features; connect features directly to solving the prospect's problem.
Handle objections by acknowledging them first before responding.
Sell on value and the solution provided, not primarily on price.
Use questions to get the prospect to articulate their needs and problems.
Ensure your proposed solution clearly addresses the prospect's identified desires or problems.
Focus the conversation on the prospect's perspective and goals.
Ask questions that uncover the underlying 'why' behind their needs or desires.
